Prime Minister Theresa May was accused of “running scared” by failing to take part in TV election debates. 
Easington MP Grahame Morris l evelled the accusation at Conservative leader Theresa May in his first appearance in the House of Commons since receiving treatment for lymphatic cancer. 
He has been away from Westminster since treatment began last year. 
The question followed the Prime Minister’s refusal to follow the example of former Prime Minister Gordon Brown, who took part in debates with leaders of opposition parties in the 2010 general election. 
Former Prime Minister David Cameron also participated in a TV debate with his opponents in the 2015 election, although he would only agree to appear in one. 
But Mrs May has ruled out any TV debates alongside her rivals. She will take part in a “Question Time”-style televised debate where members of the public can ask her questions, but will not be appear alongside rival leaders such as Labour’s Jeremy Corbyn. British Prime Minister Theresa May 
Mr Morris challenged her to take part in a debate at the Easington colliery miners welfare centre, saying she would see “the consequences of seven years of her policies on housing, of the cuts to policing and of 500 people at Walker’s losing their jobs”. 
He said: “May I ask the Prime Minister why she is running scared of the televised leadership debates?” 
But the Prime Minister said she regularly debated Mr Corbyn in the House of Commons, saying: “I have been in televised debates with the Leader of the Opposition week in and week out since I took over as Prime Minister, and I will be taking the fine record of this Conservative Government across all parts of this country.” 
The exchange took place in the final session of Prime Minister’s Questions in Parliament before the general election on June 8. 
Mrs May repeatedly highlighted her promise to provide “strong and stable leadership”, particularly when it comes to Brexit, if her Conservative Party wins the election. 
Mr Corbyn replied: “Strong leadership is about standing up for the many, not the few. But when it comes to the Prime Minister and the Conservatives, they only look after the richest, not the rest. 
“They are strong against the weak and weak against the strong.” Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn speaks at an election campaign event in Church House, London (Photo: PA) 
Broadcasters may decide to go ahead without Mrs May, and hold debates involving the opposition party leaders. 
But it now seems that Mr Corbyn could refuse to take part in any such broadcast. 
Asked whether Mr Corbyn would attend a TV debate which did not involve Mrs May, A Labour spokesman said: “Obviously, if you are talking about a debate about the possible outcomes of the election, you are talking about a debate between the Conservative Party and the Labour Party first and foremost. “To have a debate among the opposition parties doesn’t meet that objective at all. 
“I don’t think having a debate among opposition parties in any way meets the objective of giving the British people a chance of seeing what the real choices are in this election campaign. 
“Our challenge is to the Prime Minister to have the strength and guts to actually face a direct debate with Jeremy Corbyn on the issues facing the country and the issues of this election.” Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
